content.description:
Petit1 ante alios pulcherrimus omnes 
Turnus, avisavus, -i, m.: grandfather atavisatavus, -i, m.: great-grandfatherque potens, quem regiaregius, -a, -um, adj.: royal coniunx 
adiungiadiungo, -ere: to join generumgener, -i, m.: son-in-law miromirus, -a, -um, adj. = mirabilis, -e properabat amore;
sed variis portentaportentum, -i, n.: omen deumdeum = deorum terroribusterror, -is, m. = metus, -us obstantobsto, -are: to stand in the way.
 1:Lavinia (the daughter of King Latinus and Queen Amata) is the object of Petit.↩
content.question: In line 3, what does properabat mean?

unit.text: 5: Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 4, 6, 7, 11, and 12

skill.text: 1.A: Identify the meaning of Latin words and phrases.
